subject: thoughts to live by
verse: The body is a unit, though it is made up of many parts; and though all its parts are many, they form on body. So it is with Christ. (I Corinthians 12:12) NIV
reflection: Paul compares the body of Christ with a human body. Each part as a specific function that is necessary to the body as a whole. The parts are different for a purpose, and in their difference they must work together. Christians have to avoid two common errors: (1) Being proud of their abilities, ~ or (2) Thinking they have nothing to give to the body of believers. Instead of comparing ourselves to one another, we should use our different gifts, together, to spread the Good News of salvation.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, Help me to never doubt my usefulness. I know I was created for a purpose, so use me as You choose. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: For we are all baptized by one Spirit into one body whether Jew or Greek, slave or free ~ and we were all given the one Spirit to drink. (I Corinthians 12:13) NIV
reflection: We need to remember that the church is composed of many types of people from a variety of backgrounds with a multitude of gifts and abilities. It is easy for these differences to divide people as was the case in Corinth. BUT despite the differences, all believers have one thing in common ~ faith in Christ. On this essential truth the church can find unity. All believers are baptized by the one Holy Spirit into one body of believers, the church. We don't lose our individual identities, but we have an overriding oneness in Christ. When we become a Christian the Holy Spirit takes up residence in us, and we are born into God's family."We have all received the same Spirit" means that we have all received the same Holy Spirit. As members of God's family, we may have different interests and gifts, but we are united by the Spirit into one spiritual body.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I thank You for making me a part of Your family. I pray for a greater unity between the believers of Your church. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Please read these verses before going any farther (I Corinthians 12:14-24) ~ don't cheat!
reflection: Using the analogy of the body, Paul emphasizes the importance of each church member. If a seemingly insignificant part is taken away, the whole body becomes less effective. BUT thinking your gift is more important than someone else's IS an expression of spiritual pride. We should not look down on those who seem unimportant, and we should not be jealous of others who have more visible gifts. Instead, we should use the gifts we have been given and encourage others to use theirs. If we don't, the body of believers will be less effective.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, Help me to see how to better use the gifts You have given me. Help me be a better encourage to those who have not found their place in the body of believers. Amen.

Too often, unfortunately, we are jealous of those who rejoice and apathetic to those who weep ~ As believers we are in the world together ~ there is no such thing as private or individualistic Christianity. subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It is not rude, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. (I Corinthians 13:4-7) NIV
reflection: To often today our society confuses love with lust. Unlike lust God's kind of love is directed outward toward others, not inward toward ourselves. It is utterly unselfish. This kind of love goes against our natural inclinations. It is impossible to have this love unless God helps us set aside our own natural desires so that we can love and not expect anything in return. The more we become like Christ, the more love we will show to others.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, help me to set aside my sinful desires. Help me to be more loving. Help me to be more sensitive and obedient to Your Spirit's leading and guiding. Amen.

verse: Tongues, then, are a sign, not for believers but for unbelievers; Prophecy, however, is for believers, not for unbelievers. subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Women should remain silent in the churches. They are not allowed to speak, but must be in submission, as the Law says. If they want to inquire about something, they should ask their husbands at home; for it is disgraceful for a woman to speak in church. (I Corinthians 14:34, 35) NIV
reflection: Does this mean that women should not speak in church services today? It is clear from (I Corinthians 11:5) that women prayed and prophesied in public worship. It is also clear in Chapt. 12-14 that women are given spiritual gifts and are encouraged to exercise them in the body of Christ. Women have much to contribute and can participate in worship services. It may have been such a thing that the women were questioning the order of worship and cause disputes in the church that could have been settled at home. The purpose for Paul's words was to promote unity, not to teach about women's roles in the church. Remember God is ~ a God of order.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray that you would guide us to take part in church functions in an orderly fashion. Help us to agree to disagree in a loving manner when we cannot come to an agreement on some subject. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Paul says, "I am the least of the apostles and do not even deserve to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God. But by the grace of God, I am what I am, and His grace to me was not without effect. No I worked harder than all of them ~ yet not I, but the grace of God that was in me. (I Corinthians 15:9, 10) NIV
reflection: As a zealous Pharisee, Paul had been an enemy of the Christian Church, even to the point of capturing and persecuting believers (see Acts 9:1-3). So he felt unworthy to be called an apostle of Christ. But it goes without saying that He did become the most influential of the apostles. Paul was deeply humble ~ he knew that he had worked hard and had accomplished much but only because God had poured kindness and grace upon him. True humility is not convincing yourself that you are worthless but recognizing God's work in you. It is having God's perspective on who you are and acknowledging His grace in developing your abilities.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I do at times feel that I am not worthy, but seeking for sensitivity and obedience to Your Holy Spirits leading I can become what You will for me to be. Lead me in the path of righteousness. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: If only for this we have hope in Christ, we are to be pitied more than all men. But Christ has indeed been raised from the dead, the first fruits of those who have fallen asleep. (I Corinthians 15:19, 20 ) NIV
reflection: Why does Paul say believers would be miserable if there were only earthly value to Christianity? Well we need to remember that in Paul's day Christianity brought a person persecution, ostracism from family, and, in many cases, poverty. These were few tangible benefits from being a Christian in that society. It was certainly not a step up the social or career later. More important is the fact that if Christ had not been resurrected from the dead, Christian would not be forgiven of their sins or have any hope of eternal life. Now just as the first fruits of the harvest were brought to the temple as an offering, so Christ was the first to rise from the dead and never die again. He is our forerunner, the guarantee of our eventual resurrection to eternal life.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I thank You that because of Your death and resurrection, I have the guarantee of my eventual resurrection to eternal life with You in Your Kingdom. Amen.

verse: He must reign until He has put all His enemies under His feet. The last enemy to be destroyed is death. For He "has put everything under His feet." Now when it says that "everything" has been put under Him, it is clear that this does not include God Himself, who put everything under Christ. When He has done this, then the Son Himself will be made subject to Him who put everything under Him, So that God may be all in all. (I Corinthians 15:25-28) NIV
reflection: Even though God the Father and God the Son are equal, each has a special work to do and an area of sovereign control (15:28). Christ is not inferior to the Father, but His work is to defeat all evil on the earth. First, He defeated sin and death on the cross, and in the end He will defeat Satan and all evil. World events may seem to be out of control, and justice may seem to have vanished. But God is in control, allowing evil to remain for a time until He sends Jesus to earth again. Then He will present to God a perfect new world.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I thank You for Your perfect plan ~ but I pray for patience while I wait for it to come into being. Forgive me for worrying about all the sinful worldly events, help me to put my trust in You. Amen.
